qas.question: Where are old master paintings from the Germanic Rhenish territories until 1681 held?
Where are old master graphic arts until 1871 displayed?
Where are decorative arts until 1681 displayed?
Where is the city's photographic library?
Where is the international art since 1871 displayed?
When was the Musee de I'OEuvre Notre-Dame completed?
When was the Musee d'art moderne et contemporain finished?
What style of building is the Musee des Beaux-Arts?
In what year was the Musee des art decoratifs completed?
What style of building is the Musee des art decoratifs?

context: Unlike most other cities, Strasbourg's collections of European art are divided into several museums according not only to type and area, but also to epoch. Old master paintings from the <b9_0>Germanic<b9_0/> Rhenish territories and until <b5_0>1681<b5_0/> are displayed in the <a0_0>Musée de l'Œuvre Notre-Dame<a0_0/>, old master paintings from all the rest of Europe (including the Dutch Rhenish territories) and until <b8_0>1871<b8_0/> as well as old master paintings from the <b7_0>Germanic<b7_0/> Rhenish territories between 1681 and 1871 are displayed in the Musée des Beaux-Arts. Old master graphic arts until 1871 is displayed in the <a1_0>Cabinet des estampes et dessins<a1_0/>. Decorative arts until 1681 ("German period") are displayed in the <a2_0>Musée de l'Œuvre Notre-Dame<a2_0/>, decorative arts from 1681 to 1871 ("French period") are displayed in the Musée des Arts décoratifs. International art (painting, sculpture, graphic arts) and decorative art since <b6_0>1871<b6_0/> is displayed in the <a3_0><a4_0>Musée d'art moderne et contemporain<a4_0/><a3_0/>. The latter museum also displays the city's photographic library.
